Question: What is an AWS Region and how many Availability Zones does it typically contain?
OptionA: A single data center facility in a geographic location with redundant power and networking
OptionB: A cluster of data centers in a geographic location, typically containing 3-6 Availability Zones, which are isolated data centers with redundant power, networking, and connectivity
OptionC: A global network endpoint that automatically routes traffic to the nearest data center based on user location
OptionD: A collection of edge locations and content delivery points in a specific country or area
Explanation: AWS Regions are clusters of data centers in geographic locations. Each region has multiple Availability Zones (usually 3-6), which are isolated data centers with redundant power, networking, and connectivity. Regions are completely isolated from each other for fault tolerance.

Question: What factors should you consider when choosing an AWS region for your application?
OptionA: Only the cost of services and the number of available services in that region
OptionB: Compliance/data governance requirements, proximity to customers (latency), service availability, and pricing (varies by region). Data never leaves a region without explicit permission
OptionC: Only the geographic location and time zone alignment with your business operations
OptionD: Only the number of Availability Zones and the redundancy level provided by AWS
Explanation: Choose AWS regions based on: compliance/data governance requirements, proximity to customers (latency), service availability, and pricing (varies by region). Data never leaves a region without explicit permission.

Question: Which AWS services are Global (work across all regions) versus Region-scoped?
OptionA: All AWS services are global and automatically replicated across all regions without any configuration
OptionB: IAM, Route 53, CloudFront, WAF are global; EC2, Elastic Beanstalk, Lambda are region-scoped and must be explicitly replicated across regions
OptionC: All services are region-scoped and must be manually configured in each region where you want to use them
OptionD: Only compute services like EC2 and Lambda are global, while storage services are region-scoped
Explanation: AWS Global services operate across all regions: IAM, Route 53, CloudFront, WAF. Most AWS services are Region-scoped: EC2, Elastic Beanstalk, Lambda, and must be explicitly replicated across regions.

Question: What is the AWS Free Tier and what types of free offerings does it include?
OptionA: A limited-time promotion that provides all AWS services free for the first 30 days after account creation
OptionB: Always Free (S3, Lambda, DynamoDB), 12 Months Free (EC2, RDS), and Trials (various services). Some services are free forever, others for 12 months
OptionC: A credit-based system where you receive $100 in free credits to use on any AWS service for one year
OptionD: Free access to all AWS services with usage limits that reset monthly, available indefinitely for all accounts
Explanation: The AWS Free Tier allows new customers to use AWS services at no charge within certain limits. It includes: Always Free (S3, Lambda, DynamoDB), 12 Months Free (EC2, RDS), and Trials (various services).

Question: When should you use the AWS Management Console versus the AWS CLI?
OptionA: Console for automation and scripting, CLI for visual resource management and one-time tasks
OptionB: Console for visual resource management and one-time tasks, CLI for automation, scripting, programmatic access, and CI/CD pipelines
OptionC: Both tools provide identical functionality, so the choice is purely based on personal preference
OptionD: Console is for Windows users, CLI is for Linux and Mac users only
Explanation: The AWS Management Console is a web-based GUI for managing AWS resources. Use it for: visual resource management, one-time tasks, learning AWS. Use AWS CLI for: automation, scripting, programmatic access, CI/CD pipelines.

Question: What is IAM and what are its core components?
OptionA: A database service that stores user credentials and access logs with encryption at rest and in transit
OptionB: A global service that manages access to AWS resources with Users (people/apps), Groups (collections of users), Roles (temporary permissions), and Policies (JSON permission documents)
OptionC: A compute service that manages application permissions at runtime and enforces security policies dynamically
OptionD: A networking service that controls traffic flow between AWS services and provides firewall capabilities
Explanation: IAM (Identity and Access Management) is a global service that manages access to AWS resources. Core components: Users (people/apps), Groups (collections of users), Roles (temporary permissions), Policies (JSON permission documents).

Question: What is Amazon S3 and what are its key durability characteristics and primary use cases?
OptionA: A block storage service that provides persistent volumes for EC2 instances with 99.9% durability
OptionB: An object storage service for any amount of data with 99.999999999% (11 nines) durability, unlimited storage, versioning, lifecycle policies. Use cases: backup, static websites, data lakes, content distribution
OptionC: A relational database service that stores structured data with automatic backups and point-in-time recovery capabilities
OptionD: A file system service that provides shared storage across multiple EC2 instances in the same Availability Zone
Explanation: Amazon S3 is object storage for any amount of data. Key features: 99.999999999% (11 nines) durability, unlimited storage, versioning, lifecycle policies. Primary use cases: backup, static website hosting, data lakes, content distribution.

Question: What is Amazon EC2 and what are its key benefits compared to on-premises servers?
OptionA: A storage service that provides scalable object storage with automatic replication across multiple Availability Zones
OptionB: Resizable compute capacity (virtual servers) in the cloud with benefits: pay only for compute time, scalable on-demand, no upfront costs, multiple instance types and operating systems
OptionC: A database service that provides managed relational databases with automatic backups, patching, and high availability features
OptionD: A networking service that creates isolated virtual networks with complete control over IP ranges, subnets, and routing tables
Explanation: Amazon EC2 provides resizable compute capacity (virtual servers) in the cloud. Benefits: pay only for compute time, scalable on-demand, no upfront costs, multiple instance types and operating systems.

Question: What is AWS Lambda and what are its primary benefits and use cases?
OptionA: A container orchestration service that manages Docker containers across multiple EC2 instances automatically
OptionB: A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events with benefits: no server management, automatic scaling, pay per request/compute time, integrated with AWS services. Use cases: event-driven apps, microservices, data processing
OptionC: A virtual machine service that provides resizable compute capacity with pay-as-you-go pricing and multiple instance types
OptionD: A workflow orchestration service that coordinates multiple AWS services to build complex applications with visual workflows
Explanation: AWS Lambda is a serverless compute service that runs code in response to events. Benefits: no server management, automatic scaling, pay per request/compute time, integrated with AWS services. Use cases: event-driven apps, microservices, data processing.

Question: What databases does Amazon RDS support and what are its key management benefits?
OptionA: Only MySQL and PostgreSQL with manual backup and patching requirements
OptionB: MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, Oracle, SQL Server, and Aurora with automated backups, patching, monitoring, scaling, and high availability with Multi-AZ deployments
OptionC: Only NoSQL databases like DynamoDB with automatic scaling and global distribution capabilities
OptionD: Only in-memory databases like Redis and Memcached with sub-millisecond latency for caching workloads
Explanation: Amazon RDS is a managed relational database service supporting MySQL, PostgreSQL, MariaDB, Oracle, SQL Server, and Aurora. Benefits: automated backups, patching, monitoring, scaling, high availability with Multi-AZ deployments.

Question: What is an AWS VPC and what level of network control does it provide?
OptionA: A global network service that automatically routes traffic between AWS services without any configuration required
OptionB: A logically isolated network where you launch AWS resources with complete control over IP ranges, subnets, route tables, and network gateways for private networking and network segmentation
OptionC: A content delivery network that caches content at edge locations worldwide to reduce latency for end users
OptionD: A domain name system service that routes internet traffic to AWS resources using various routing policies like weighted and latency-based routing
Explanation: AWS VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) is a logically isolated network where you launch AWS resources. Features: complete control over IP ranges, subnets, route tables, network gateways. Enables private networking and network segmentation for security.

Question: What is AWS CloudFormation and how does it enable Infrastructure as Code?
OptionA: A deployment service that automatically deploys application code to EC2 instances with zero downtime using blue-green deployments
OptionB: A service that enables Infrastructure as Code using JSON/YAML templates to provision and manage resources with benefits: reproducible infrastructure, version control, automated deployments, rollback capability
OptionC: A monitoring service that tracks AWS resource configurations and sends alerts when changes are detected, ensuring compliance with organizational policies
OptionD: A backup service that automatically creates snapshots of AWS resources on a schedule and stores them in S3 with lifecycle management policies
Explanation: AWS CloudFormation enables Infrastructure as Code (IaC). You define resources in JSON/YAML templates, and CloudFormation provisions and manages them. Benefits: reproducible infrastructure, version control, automated deployments, rollback capability.

Question: What is AWS Elastic Beanstalk and what types of applications benefit most from it?
OptionA: A container orchestration service that manages Docker containers and Kubernetes clusters with automatic scaling and load balancing
OptionB: A Platform as a Service (PaaS) that handles deployment, capacity provisioning, load balancing, and auto-scaling automatically. Best for web applications, quick deployments, and minimal infrastructure management
OptionC: A serverless compute service that runs code in response to events without provisioning or managing servers, ideal for event-driven applications
OptionD: A database service that provides managed relational databases with automatic backups, patching, and high availability across multiple Availability Zones
Explanation: AWS Elastic Beanstalk is a Platform as a Service (PaaS) that handles deployment, capacity provisioning, load balancing, auto-scaling, and application health monitoring. You just upload code. Best for: web applications, quick deployments, minimal infrastructure management.

Question: What services work with AWS Auto Scaling and what can trigger scaling events?
OptionA: Only EC2 instances with triggers limited to CPU utilization and network traffic metrics
OptionB: EC2, ECS, DynamoDB, and Aurora. Triggers include CloudWatch metrics (CPU, network, custom), scheduled scaling, and predictive scaling
OptionC: Only Lambda functions with triggers based on the number of incoming requests and execution duration
OptionD: Only S3 buckets with triggers based on storage size and number of objects stored in each bucket
Explanation: AWS Auto Scaling automatically adjusts capacity to maintain performance at the lowest cost. It works with EC2, ECS, DynamoDB, and Aurora. Triggers include: CloudWatch metrics (CPU, network, custom), scheduled scaling, and predictive scaling.

Question: What are the key features of Amazon CloudWatch for monitoring AWS resources?
OptionA: Only real-time metrics collection with 1-minute granularity and automatic alerting when thresholds are exceeded
OptionB: Metrics (performance data), logs (application logs), alarms (notifications/actions), and dashboards (visualization) for real-time monitoring of AWS resources and applications
OptionC: Only log aggregation and search capabilities with retention periods up to 30 days and integration with third-party log analysis tools
OptionD: Only cost tracking and billing alerts that notify you when spending exceeds budget thresholds with detailed cost breakdowns by service
Explanation: Amazon CloudWatch is a monitoring and observability service. Features: metrics (performance data), logs (application logs), alarms (notifications/actions), dashboards (visualization). It monitors AWS resources and applications in real-time.

Question: What is Amazon Route 53 and what routing policies does it support?
OptionA: A content delivery network that caches content at edge locations worldwide and routes users to the nearest cache based on geographic location
OptionB: A scalable DNS web service with functions: domain registration, DNS routing, health checks, traffic management. Routing policies: Simple, Weighted, Latency-based, Failover, Geolocation, Multi-value
OptionC: A load balancing service that distributes incoming application traffic across multiple EC2 instances in different Availability Zones for high availability
OptionD: A network acceleration service that uses AWS global network infrastructure to improve performance for applications by routing traffic over private AWS network
Explanation: Amazon Route 53 is a scalable DNS web service. Functions: domain registration, DNS routing, health checks, traffic management. Routing policies: Simple, Weighted, Latency-based, Failover, Geolocation, Multi-value.

Question: What are Security Groups and what are their key characteristics regarding traffic rules?
OptionA: Physical firewalls that are deployed at data center level and control all network traffic entering and leaving AWS facilities
OptionB: Virtual firewalls for EC2 instances that are stateful (allow inbound automatically allows outbound response), operate at instance level, default deny all inbound, allow all outbound
OptionC: Network access control lists that operate at the subnet level and provide stateless filtering of traffic with explicit allow and deny rules
OptionD: Load balancers that distribute incoming traffic across multiple instances and perform health checks to ensure only healthy instances receive traffic
Explanation: Security Groups are virtual firewalls for EC2 instances. Key characteristics: stateful (allow inbound automatically allows outbound response), operate at instance level, default deny all inbound, allow all outbound. Rules control traffic by protocol, port, and source/destination.

Question: What are the three types of Elastic Load Balancers in AWS and when should each be used?
OptionA: Only Application Load Balancer and Network Load Balancer, with Classic Load Balancer being deprecated
OptionB: Application Load Balancer (ALB) for HTTP/HTTPS Layer 7, Network Load Balancer (NLB) for TCP/UDP Layer 4 high performance, Classic Load Balancer (CLB) legacy. ALB supports content-based routing, SSL termination, container targets
OptionC: Only Gateway Load Balancer for Layer 3 IP protocol traffic routing to third-party security appliances like firewalls and intrusion detection systems
OptionD: All load balancers are identical in functionality, with the only difference being the pricing model and regional availability
Explanation: AWS offers three load balancer types: Application Load Balancer (ALB) for HTTP/HTTPS Layer 7, Network Load Balancer (NLB) for TCP/UDP Layer 4 high performance, Classic Load Balancer (CLB) legacy. ALB supports content-based routing, SSL termination, and container targets.

Question: How do Auto Scaling Groups work with Elastic Load Balancing to provide high availability?
OptionA: Auto Scaling Groups only manage instance lifecycle, while Load Balancers handle all traffic distribution and health checking independently
OptionB: Auto Scaling Groups ensure correct number of instances; ELB distributes traffic across healthy instances, replaces unhealthy ones, scales based on demand, maintains minimum/maximum/desired capacity
OptionC: Auto Scaling Groups automatically create Load Balancers for each group, but they cannot be configured separately and must use default settings
OptionD: Load Balancers are required only for public-facing applications, while Auto Scaling Groups work independently for internal applications without any integration
Explanation: Auto Scaling Groups ensure the correct number of EC2 instances are running. They work with ELB to: distribute traffic across healthy instances, replace unhealthy instances, scale based on demand, maintain minimum/maximum/desired capacity.

Question: What recommendations does AWS Trusted Advisor provide and which support plans include full access?
OptionA: Only cost optimization recommendations for EC2 and S3 services, available to all AWS accounts regardless of support plan
OptionB: Cost Optimization, Security, Performance, and Fault Tolerance recommendations. Full access requires Business or Enterprise support plans, Basic plan shows limited checks
OptionC: Only security recommendations for IAM policies and access keys, available exclusively to Enterprise support plan customers
OptionD: Only performance recommendations for database and application optimization, available to Developer and higher support plans with additional configuration required
Explanation: AWS Trusted Advisor provides real-time best practice recommendations in: Cost Optimization, Security, Performance, Fault Tolerance. Full access requires Business or Enterprise support plans. Basic plan shows limited checks.

Question: What does AWS CloudTrail log and how does it help with security auditing and compliance?
OptionA: Only user login attempts and authentication failures with IP addresses and timestamps for security monitoring
OptionB: Who made API calls, what service was called, when it happened, where from (IP), result. Logs stored in S3. Essential for security auditing and compliance
OptionC: Only resource configuration changes and modifications to security groups and network ACLs for change tracking purposes
OptionD: Only billing and cost-related API calls with detailed pricing information and usage metrics for financial auditing and budget planning
Explanation: AWS CloudTrail records AWS API calls for governance, compliance, and auditing. It logs: who made the call, what service was called, when it happened, where from (IP), result. Logs are stored in S3 buckets. Essential for security auditing and compliance.

Question: What are the key benefits of using AWS Organizations for managing multiple AWS accounts?
OptionA: Only consolidated billing across all accounts with automatic cost allocation and budget alerts for each account
OptionB: Consolidated billing, account-wide policies via Service Control Policies (SCPs), easier account creation and management, shared payment methods. Useful for enterprises managing multiple accounts
OptionC: Only centralized IAM user management where users can access multiple accounts with single sign-on capabilities and unified permissions
OptionD: Only automated backup and disaster recovery coordination across accounts with cross-region replication and centralized recovery procedures
Explanation: AWS Organizations centralizes management of multiple AWS accounts. Benefits: consolidated billing, account-wide policies via Service Control Policies (SCPs), easier account creation and management, shared payment methods. Useful for enterprises managing multiple accounts.

Question: What are the five pillars of the AWS Well-Architected Framework?
OptionA: Security, Cost, Performance, Reliability, and Scalability as the core principles for building cloud applications
OptionB: Operational Excellence (run/monitor systems), Security (protect information), Reliability (recover from failures), Performance Efficiency (use resources efficiently), Cost Optimization (avoid unnecessary costs)
OptionC: Availability, Durability, Scalability, Performance, and Cost as the fundamental requirements for all AWS architectures
OptionD: Compliance, Governance, Monitoring, Automation, and Disaster Recovery as the essential components of enterprise cloud strategies
Explanation: The AWS Well-Architected Framework has five pillars: Operational Excellence (run/monitor systems), Security (protect information), Reliability (recover from failures), Performance Efficiency (use resources efficiently), Cost Optimization (avoid unnecessary costs).

Question: How does the AWS Shared Responsibility Model divide security responsibilities between AWS and customers?
OptionA: AWS handles all security aspects including data encryption, access control, and network security, with customers only responsible for application code
OptionB: AWS manages security OF the cloud (infrastructure, hardware, software, networking, facilities). Customer manages security IN the cloud (data, configurations, access management, encryption, network traffic)
OptionC: Customers are responsible for all security including infrastructure, networking, and data protection, while AWS only provides the physical data centers
OptionD: Security responsibilities are shared equally between AWS and customers with joint accountability for all security measures and compliance requirements
Explanation: The AWS Shared Responsibility Model divides security responsibilities: AWS manages security OF the cloud (infrastructure, hardware, software, networking, facilities). Customer manages security IN the cloud (data, configurations, access management, encryption, network traffic).

Question: What are the different AWS Support Plans and what features differentiate them?
OptionA: Only Basic (free) and Enterprise (paid) plans with Enterprise providing 24/7 phone support and dedicated technical account manager
OptionB: Basic (free - account/billing support), Developer ($29/month - business hours email), Business ($100/month - 24/7 support, TAM), Enterprise (custom - all Business features plus dedicated TAM, support API)
OptionC: Only Developer and Business plans with both providing identical support levels but different pricing based on account usage and number of resources
OptionD: All support plans provide the same level of technical support, with pricing differences based only on the number of support tickets submitted per month
Explanation: AWS Support Plans: Basic (free) - account/billing support, documentation; Developer ($29/month) - business hours email support; Business ($100/month) - 24/7 phone/email/chat, technical account manager, Infrastructure Event Management; Enterprise (custom) - all Business features plus dedicated TAM, support API, better SLA.

Question: What is AWS Marketplace and what are its primary benefits?
OptionA: A service catalog that lists only AWS-managed services and solutions with standardized pricing and deployment templates
OptionB: A digital catalog with thousands of third-party software solutions offering quick deployment (click to launch), billing through AWS account, tested on AWS infrastructure, categories: AMIs, SaaS, container images, data products
OptionC: A monitoring dashboard that tracks software usage across AWS accounts and provides recommendations for optimizing software licenses and costs
OptionD: A certification program that validates third-party software for AWS compatibility and provides quality assurance testing for enterprise customers
Explanation: AWS Marketplace is a digital catalog with thousands of third-party software solutions. Benefits: quick deployment (click to launch), billing through AWS account, tested on AWS infrastructure, categories: AMIs, SaaS, container images, data products.

Question: What are the main AWS pricing models and what are their key characteristics?
OptionA: Only On-Demand pricing with pay-as-you-go model and no discounts available for any level of commitment
OptionB: On-Demand (pay as you go, no commitment), Reserved Instances (1-3 year commitment, up to 75% discount), Savings Plans (flexible, compute discount), Spot Instances (bid for unused capacity, up to 90% discount, can be interrupted)
OptionC: Only Reserved Instances with 1-year and 3-year terms providing fixed pricing regardless of actual usage or demand fluctuations
OptionD: All pricing is the same across all services with standardized rates per hour regardless of instance type, region, or usage patterns
Explanation: AWS Pricing Models: On-Demand (pay as you go, no commitment), Reserved Instances (1-3 year commitment, up to 75% discount), Savings Plans (flexible, compute discount), Spot Instances (bid for unused capacity, up to 90% discount, can be interrupted).

Question: What are the advantages of using IAM Roles instead of access keys for AWS service permissions?
OptionA: Access keys provide better security with automatic rotation and fine-grained permissions compared to IAM Roles
OptionB: Automatic credential rotation, no key management, fine-grained permissions, used by EC2 instances, Lambda functions, cross-account access. More secure than access keys
OptionC: IAM Roles require manual credential management and rotation, while access keys are automatically managed by AWS with built-in security features
OptionD: Access keys and IAM Roles provide identical functionality with no security or management differences, making the choice purely based on personal preference
Explanation: IAM Roles provide temporary credentials to AWS services or users without storing long-term access keys. Benefits: automatic credential rotation, no key management, fine-grained permissions, used by EC2 instances, Lambda functions, and cross-account access. More secure than access keys.

Question: How does AWS resource tagging help with cost tracking and resource management?
OptionA: Tags are automatically applied by AWS based on resource type and cannot be customized or modified by users
OptionB: Allows metadata labels on resources for cost allocation (track spending by project/department), automation (scripts can filter by tags), resource organization, compliance tracking. Tags are key-value pairs
OptionC: Tags are used only for visual organization in the AWS Console and do not affect billing, automation, or any operational functionality
OptionD: Resource tagging is available only for EC2 and S3 services with limited tag options that cannot be customized for organizational needs
Explanation: AWS Resource Tagging allows metadata labels on resources. Benefits: cost allocation (track spending by project/department), automation (scripts can filter by tags), resource organization, compliance tracking. Tags are key-value pairs (e.g., Environment:Production, Project:WebApp).

Question: How can you check AWS service limits and why do these limits exist?
OptionA: Service limits are fixed and cannot be checked or modified, with all accounts having identical limits regardless of usage or requirements
OptionB: Check limits in Service Quotas console, request increases via Support Center. Limits exist per region per account to protect from unexpected costs and ensure fair resource allocation
OptionC: Service limits are automatically adjusted based on account usage and billing history, requiring no manual intervention or monitoring
OptionD: All AWS services have unlimited capacity with no restrictions or limits, allowing unrestricted resource provisioning for all customers
Explanation: AWS Service Limits (quotas) protect you from unexpected costs and ensure fair resource allocation. Default limits vary by service (e.g., EC2 instance limits, S3 bucket limits). Check limits in Service Quotas console, request increases via Support Center. Limits exist per region per account.
